citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care.
citations.narrative:
On October 1st & 3rd, 2024 expired anesthetic agents were used on a total of 19 pigs for sedation prior to surgery,
sedation prior to euthanasia and for euthanasia. This issue was identified during a controlled substance audit by the
facility.
Use of anesthetic agents for sedation, anesthesia and euthanasia is always a risk, and it is not possible to predict how
each animal will respond. Although the intended outcome was achieved in the animals, the use of expired anesthetic
agents increases the risk that animals may not respond to the agents as intended/anticipated, and therefore, increase the
risk of a negative impact on their welfare.
Each research facility must establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that provide adequate guidance
to personnel involved in the care and use of animals regarding handling, immobilization, anesthesia. analgesia,
tranquilization, and euthanasia.
To be corrected going forward from or on June 13, 2024

On February 14, 2025, at 8:30am two adult dogs were found by animal care staff in holding crates, intended as temporary
holding enclosures while their primary enclosures were being cleaned. The dogs were in a dog housing room with no
access to water, having been in the crates overnight. The dogs, which had no prior health concerns, were examined by a
staff veterinarian that same morning with no signs of dehydration or ill effect.
Constant access to potable water is necessary to ensure that dogs remain hydrated as needed throughout the day. The
facility must ensure that all dogs have continuous access to potable water, unless restricted by the attending veterinarian
or except as provided in 3.17(a).
To be corrected going forward from or on June 13, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.33(b)(4) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care. 
On October 1st & 3rd, 2024 expired anesthetic agents were used on a total of 19 pigs for sedation prior to surgery, 
sedation prior to euthanasia and for euthanasia. This issue was identified during a controlled substance audit by the 
facility.  
 
Use of anesthetic agents for sedation, anesthesia and euthanasia is always a risk, and it is not possible to predict how 
each animal will respond. Although the intended outcome was achieved in the animals, the use of expired anesthetic 
agents increases the risk that animals may not respond to the agents as intended/anticipated, and therefore, increase the 
risk of a negative impact on their welfare. 
 
Each research facility must establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that provide adequate guidance 
to personnel involved in the care and use of animals regarding handling, immobilization, anesthesia. analgesia, 
tranquilization, and euthanasia. 
To be corrected going forward from or on June 13, 2024 
3.10(a) 
   
Watering 
On February 14, 2025, at 8:30am two adult dogs were found by animal care staff in holding crates, intended as temporary 
holding enclosures while their primary enclosures were being cleaned. The dogs were in a dog housing room with no 
access to water, having been in the crates overnight. The dogs, which had no prior health concerns, were examined by a 
staff veterinarian that same morning with no signs of dehydration or ill effect.  
Constant access to potable water is necessary to ensure that dogs remain hydrated as needed throughout the day. The 
facility must ensure that all dogs have continuous access to potable water, unless restricted by the attending veterinarian 
or except as provided in 3.17(a). 
To be corrected going forward from or on June 13, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.

n
